message_1: A sample of 500 mg of a radioactive substance has a half-life of 10 days. Write an equation that models the amount of substance remaining after "t" days and find how much of the substance will remain after 30 days.
message_2:
To model the amount of a radioactive substance remaining after "t" days, we can use the exponential decay formula:

A(t) = A₀ * (1/2)^(t/T)

where:
- A(t) is the amount of the substance remaining after "t" days
- A₀ is the initial amount of the substance (in this case, 500 mg)
- (1/2) is the decay factor, since the substance has a half-life
- t is the time in days
- T is the half-life of the substance (in this case, 10 days)

So, the equation that models the amount of substance remaining after "t" days is:

A(t) = 500 * (1/2)^(t/10)

Now, we want to find how much of the substance will remain after 30 days. We can plug "t = 30" into the equation:

A(30) = 500 * (1/2)^(30/10)

A(30) = 500 * (1/2)^3

A(30) = 500 * (1/8)

A(30) = 62.5 mg

So, after 30 days, 62.5 mg of the radioactive substance will remain.
